title: ValueError: Unable to expand environment variable in host setting
body:
### Environment information

* eth-brownie>=1.10.0,<2.0.0
* `ganache-cli` Version: 6.12.2
* `solc` Version: 0.6.6
* Python Version: 3.8.5
* OS: linux (ubuntu 20.04)

### What was wrong?

Please include information like:

* what command you ran
`brownie run scripts/simple_collectible/deploy_simple.py --network rinkeby`

* the code that caused the failure (see [this link](https://help.github.com/articles/basic-writing-and-formatting-syntax/) for help with formatting code)

* full output of the error you received
```
NftMixProject is the active project.
  File "brownie/_cli/__main__.py", line 64, in main
    importlib.import_module(f"brownie._cli.{cmd}").main()
  File "brownie/_cli/run.py", line 43, in main
    network.connect(CONFIG.argv["network"])
  File "brownie/network/main.py", line 40, in connect
    web3.connect(host, active.get("timeout", 30))
  File "brownie/network/web3.py", line 51, in connect
    uri = _expand_environment_vars(uri)
  File "brownie/network/web3.py", line 171, in _expand_environment_vars
    raise ValueError(f"Unable to expand environment variable in host setting: '{uri}'")
ValueError: Unable to expand environment variable in host setting: 'https://rinkeby.infura.io/v3/$WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID'
```
### How can it be fixed?

Fill this in if you know how the bug could be fixed.

You need to sign up for an Infura API key and store it in an environment variable `WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID`

The documentation has more details: https://eth-brownie.readthedocs.io/en/stable/network-management.html#using-infura

Looks like this is from the new `.env` file improvement. https://eth-brownie.readthedocs.io/en/stable/config.html?highlight=.env#dotenv

It's not pulling in env variables at the project level, so I can't use the `.env` variables in my project, only in my yaml. Is this the intended effect? I'm running into the same issue.
cc @omarish
Having this work globally would be great... even at the networking level, although it looks like that might be tricky.

For clarity, the original improvement that went in was good :) 

This would be a new one, to allow the `.env` vars to work across scripts too. And ideally you could set your `WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID` in the `.env` file too

Great call. I can add that in!

> On Apr 5, 2021, at 16:36, Patrick Collins ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> ﻿
> For clarity, the original improvement that went in was good :)
> 
> This would be a new one, to allow the .env vars to work across scripts too. And ideally you could set your WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID in the .env file too
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.

So, in my `.env` file I could simply have:
```
export WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID=xxxx
```
And then I should be able to do both:

1. Connect to a network (expand the host env var from the .env file)

`brownie run some_script.py --network rinkeby`
^ This script runs without complaining about a web3 key since it's in the `.env` file. 

2. And in my script run something like:
```
import os

print(os.getenv("WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID")
```

And it prints out correctly.

The way the network currently connects, is this something we could do?

Yup, this is definitely something we can do. I started off loading these very cautiously (always pays to be cautious in crypto) but could definitely make this change. Looks good to you, @iamdefinitelyahuman?
Bumping this, it would help my tutorials a lot :) @omarish @iamdefinitelyahuman
I think this should be working since this got merged: https://github.com/eth-brownie/brownie/pull/1063. Let me know if not and I can take a look.

I ran into this problem today, actually trying to follow @PatrickAlphaC tutorial - any recommended workaround? I'm typically mobile developer making phone apps, so working with any of this is very new to me
@welshm, are you still running into this issue?

I haven't tried - I'll need to update my installation first I assume

Mike W.
Can we close this? It appears to have been fixed

Yes - do you want me to close it since I opened it?

Sent from my iPhone

I just can't is all @welshm ahah

Hi @PatrickAlphaC I'm following you tutorial and I've encountered the following issue `ValueError: Unable to expand environment variable in host setting: 'https://rinkeby.infura.io/v3/$WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID'` Can you please help?

@redcloud86 , try adding **WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID** in User Variables to see if it solves your problem (follow https://www.twilio.com/blog/2017/01/how-to-set-environment-variables.html). You may need to restart the computer.

> @redcloud86 , try adding **WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID** in User Variables to see if it solves your problem (follow https://www.twilio.com/blog/2017/01/how-to-set-environment-variables.html). You may need to restart the computer.

Thanks @sheaky278 I tried setting my environment variables using the guide you sent but I still get the error:  
`ValueError: Unable to expand environment variable in host setting: 'https://rinkeby.infura.io/v3/$WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID'`

 I'm not sure what I'm doing wrong

@redcloud86 , did you register an account, open a new project in https://infura.io/, copy the **PROJECT ID** from there and paste the **PROJECT ID** in your User Variables?
I'm sorry if this doesn't help you, it works for me though.

I've just run into this issue as well while following @PatrickAlphaC's tutorial.
I'm running brownie v1.16.4.
```
BrownieSimpleStorageProject is the active project.
  File "brownie/_cli/__main__.py", line 64, in main
    importlib.import_module(f"brownie._cli.{cmd}").main()
  File "brownie/_cli/run.py", line 43, in main
    network.connect(CONFIG.argv["network"])
  File "brownie/network/main.py", line 40, in connect
    web3.connect(host, active.get("timeout", 30))
  File "brownie/network/web3.py", line 52, in connect
    uri = _expand_environment_vars(uri)
  File "brownie/network/web3.py", line 183, in _expand_environment_vars
    raise ValueError(f"Unable to expand environment variable in host setting: '{uri}'")
ValueError: Unable to expand environment variable in host setting: 'https://rinkeby.infura.io/v3/$WEB3_INFURA_PROJECT_ID'
```

Okay I've just realised what my problem is - the brownie-config.yaml file has to be at the root of the project e.g
* my-sample-project
  * brownie-config.yaml
  * .env 

@redcloud86 maybe try that?

Had the exact same problem WIN10. 

Just added a new global variable via Control Panel using this tutorial: https://www.twilio.com/blog/2017/01/how-to-set-environment-variables.html

Restarted my PC

This sorted out the issue

> @redcloud86 , did you register an account, open a new project in https://infura.io/, copy the **PROJECT ID** from there and paste the **PROJECT ID** in your User Variables? I'm sorry if this doesn't help you, it works for me though.

Thanks @sheaky278 it was another I issue and is working now

> Okay I've just realised what my problem is - the brownie-config.yaml file has to be at the root of the project e.g
> 
> * my-sample-project
>   
>   * brownie-config.yaml
>   * .env
> 
> @redcloud86 maybe try that?

thanks for the suggestion @tobiade I managed to figure it out

I having another issue when running `brownie run scripts/simple_collectible/deploy_simple.py --network rinkeby`

This is the error I get `ValueError: insufficient funds for gas * price + value`

Does anyone else get this error? I read that you need some test ETH in your Rinkeby test network, I tried to get some from the rinkeby faucet but I was unsuccessul.

So I ran into this issue while I was doing `test_lottery_unit.py` of @PatrickAlphaC 's tutorial.

This might help you guys. Add this to the script

```
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()
```

> Okay I've just realised what my problem is - the brownie-config.yaml file has to be at the root of the project e.g
> 
> * my-sample-project
>   
>   * brownie-config.yaml
>   * .env
> 
> @redcloud86 maybe try that?

This solved it for me too...oops!

@dfjh82 - your brownie-config.yaml file should be at the root of your project like [this](https://imgur.com/hNn2p3x).
